tweets.text: There is literally a split second where it works perfectly and then it messes up again, so clearly it is capable of doing what I want and is choosing not to

What are the correct search terms for taking a shapefile with data, changing boundaries, and recalculating the data geospatially based on how the boundaries changed. Like if I wanted to take counties with population data and rearrange them but have new shapes w/ correctish pop.
Unfortunately I was right. https://t.co/HzXZtoTKw5 https://t.co/FDuAQhYwH9

This is interesting and coincides with my latest dorky interest in writing my own Markdown parser. I wonder what a journalism-centric version of Markdown where you can annotate sourcing and confidence really clearly would look like. https://t.co/VLleOw5qqy

I think America would greatly benefit by an Office-style sitcom set in a newsroom, or, alternatively a Big Brother-style reality show but its all journalists who need to write 4 blogs a day and a feature a week.

All left up to a good author to untangle, explain and present, or often, not. Very hard to automate. Not much Silicon Valley app-appeal. Would every news consumer benefit from a better approach? Yes. Would they pay for it? Maybe.

How many of the facts being stated have been confirmed? By the author or another reporter? By two sources or 15? Is this a new fact or an old one? What context do I need to understand what is new and why it matters?

Journalism needs a “view source” or “inspect process” the same way web developers do - all facts and people are intertwined and in the year 2019 we interact primarily with the equivalent of paper printouts of an authors understanding at a particular time, plus color

In some kind of incredible super-happy super-loving post-amazing-show mood. I love it.
Just got home, downed a bottle of snapple and then threw it up. Feel great now. Ahh.
At the end of the naked citizens show, it was fucking magnificent.
Moshing and dancing to the naked citizens and having a kickass time! Fuck yeah!
